text:
**Complete review in Indonesian language (Tinjauan lengkap dalam Bahasa Indonesia)

Catatan dari peninjau**

Saya memilih untuk meninjau makalah dari Indonesia, ditulis dalam Bahasa Indonesia oleh orang Indonesia untuk memperlihatkan kepada komunitas sains internasional keragaman ilmu, bahasa, konteks lokal yang melatarbelakani sebuah makalah, dan tingkat sains yang dikuasai penulis atau yang tersedia fasilitasnya di perguruan tinggi sebagai dasar dari penulisan suatu makalah. Di sini saya juga menekankan bahwa penunjau (reviewer) tidak boleh dipengaruhi oleh perspektif umum ketertinggalan suatu bangsa dalam sains dan menggunakannya untuk menilai suatu makalah. Peninjau perlu melihat pula sumbangsih makalah kepada kebutuhan atau masalah lokal. Tidak semua makalah ditulis untuk menyelesaikan masalah dunia.

Saya akan menuliskan tinjauan umum dalam Bahasa Inggris dan Indonesia, dan menuliskan komentar spesifik di beberapa lokasi menggunakan Bahasa Indonesia.

**Komentar umum
**
    Makalah ini sangat penting untuk kondisi Indonesia saat ini yang secara terus-menerus didera bencana alam, karena itu makalah ini perlu diekspos di media. Dihubungkan dengan krisis tsunami Selat Sunda saat ini, produk ini sangat relevan dan dibutuhkan.
    Pengujian lebih lanjut pada berbagai lingkungan lokal akan meningkatkan disain tenda, pemilihan material dan teknik mendirikannya. Teknik mendirikan tenda juga perlu menjadi salah satu variabel uji mengingat lahan terdampak tsunami biasanya akan tertutup lapisan lumpur tebal yang lunak.
    Kerjasama dengan peneliti dengan latar belakang ilmu material akan sangat baik untuk meningkatkan spesifikasi tenda versi selanjutnya.  

**Komentar spesifik
**
**    Metode:**
        Tim penulis perlu memasukkan proses seleksi material secara lebih rinci ke dalam makalah, karena ini adalah bagian terpenting, menurut saya. Fakta bahwa dokumen ini berdasarkan riset multi tahun perlu ditekankan oleh tim penulis, salah satunya adalah dengan menyitir dokumen sebelumnya dan mengunggahnya secara daring sebagai material pendukung. 

**    Pengembangan lebih lanjut:
**        Makalah ini perlu dikembangkan dengan menambahkan variabel kondisi lapangan lokal ke tahap pemilihan bahan dan teknik mendirikannya di lokasi.
        Tim penulis juga perlu menguji material, disain, dan teknik mendirikannya berdasarkan standar tenda yang saat ini ada: misal dari UNHCR (United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees), IFRC (International Federation of Red Cross). Bilamana SNI (Standar Nasional Indonesia) atau BNPB dan Basarnas telah memiliki standar serupa, saya mendorong tim penulis untuk menggunakannya.
        Untuk memberikan informasi lebih banyak kepada pembaca, saya menyarankan tim penulis untuk mengunggah dokumen/laporan sebelumnya dan material tambahan lainnya ke server OSF (karena OSF membolehkan unggahan berbagai jenis dokumen dan format).
        Akan sangat menarik bila tim penulis dapat menguji tenda langsung di lokasi terdampak bencana dan mengundang lembaga terkait untuk memberikan tinjauan (misal dari BNPB atau Basarnas).
        Berbagai komparasi dengan tenda yang saat ini ada dan digunakan oleh BNPB/Basarnas akan sangat strategis untuk ditambahkan ke dalam makalah selanjutnya. Berbagai kelebihan dan kekurangan disain tenda ini perlu dieksplorasi untuk meningkatkan kualitas tenda versi selanjutnya.
        Saya menyarankan kerjasama antara tim penulis dengan ahli material untuk meningkatkan kualitas tenda versi berikutnya.

**Komentar penutup**

Dengan mempublikasikan riset ini dalam Bahasa Indonesia, tim penulis menekankan untuk berkontribusi secara langsung kepada masyarakat, alih-alih, mengejar reputasi personal dengan mempublikasikannya di jurnal internasional.

**Notes from reviewer**

I choose to review an article from Indonesia and written by Indonesians to show international readers the diversity of science, language, local context as the  background of the paper, and the level of science that plays as the basis of the papers. Here I also point out that reviewers should not be influenced by common perspective on the level of science in SE Asia (especially Indonesia) and then use that measurement to assess the paper, rather, the reviewers should understand the benefits of the paper for local problems. Not all papers were written to solve the world's largest problem.    

I will be writing the overview of the comment in English and Indonesian language and write more specific comments in various locations only in Indonesian language.   

**General comment**

* This paper is very important to the current situation in Indonesia, which suffering from many and continuous geohazards, hence this paper should be properly exposed in Indonesian media, concerning current tsunami situations.

* More testing in various local environments should be conducted to improve the tent's design and how to set it up under eg: soft ground after tsunami.  

**Specific comments**

* Methods: 

 ** the author should include the material selection process in the method, because this is the most important bit in this paper. The fact that this was a multi years project should be pointed out in form of citation to the previous documents. 

* Future development: 

 **this article should be developed further by including the variability of local condition to the material selection process.

 ** the authors should also test the material and design with the existing standards for shelters, eg: from [UNHCR (United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees)](https://emergency.unhcr.org/entry/254351/shelter-solutions), [IFRC (International Federation of Red Cross)](https://www.ifrc.org/PageFiles/95526/publications/D.03.a.07.%20IFRC%20shelter-kit-guidelines-EN-LR.pdf).

 ** to give more information, I suggest the authors to upload the previous documents/reports and all suplementary materials to the [OSF](osf.io) (since the OSF allows them to upload multiple files in various formats).

 ** it would be interesting as well to test out the tent in the field and share the comments from the authorities (eg [BNPB](https://bnpb.go.id) or [Basarnas](http://www.basarnas.go.id)).


**Closing comment**

By publishing this research in Indonesian language, the authors have made their main point to directly contribute to the society instead of only chasing their fame by publishing it in international journal.

Full editorial history can be found here:
https://osf.io/ayuxz/

I don't mean to emphasise speedy eval here too much as being the end-goal. It is more that I want to highlight that being methodical does not *have* to be arduous and involved. 

It's tough to estimate, because I was writing the paper up and doing other research master courses at the same time as I was doing it. If we are talking about going from the very start, downloading the articles to having the finished results (usable personally, but not written up), I would say a few days of solid work. The time investment is flexible though, because one can determine for oneself how wide to cast the net in the first case. While I would recommend casting the net wide, I can see situations where using BFs and a following qual assessment on a handful of papers if you've already got some in mind and would like to be more methodical about your selection to a final target could be justifiable. In such a case, the execution could be very fast, esp given that we provide the code with which to do the reanalysis.
Definitely. Suggestions about this would be a good addition to this section.

I don't disagree, but I do think that it's a little outside of the scope of the method we demonstrate to delve into the adequacy of other groups' methodology. I understand the criticisms of self-report, but if I were to engage on this point, I would err on the side of (for instance) recommending possibilities for extension of the approach involving objective tests of behaviour. But again, I think that although you make an important point, the discussion is a tad 'rabbit-hole-y' and is outside of what we are trying to do with this particular article.
I like this idea very much.

I agonized a little about this. I find the approaches of some metascience groups needlessly destructive, and wanted to try to get the reader to focus on the method rather than the articles we used in its demonstration. We originally had named and cited the papers, but changed to a numbered list so the articles featured in the demonstrations were less prominent. There's probably a sweet spot for being concise and practical without pointing fingers or being destructive, but I haven't found it yet.

I don't think so. No one strong original result in favour of a given hypothesis is the entire story. The same goes for replications, even if we are talking about a pure replication. Although one compelling replication helps clear up the view, it would be remiss to keep it at that. I think one possible exception though is if one were to conduct a replication using the 'robust tests of theory' approach as Baribault and colleagues describe: https://osf.io/g84py/.

Our choice to stick with sig. results could have done with some justification. We have two reasons: 1. Although IMO stat. sig. is hardly diagnostic of a true effect, the lack of stat. sig. being related to no effect is even more complicated. I don't even know what it would mean if one were to try to replicate a non sig. result (I would argue that the case is different if one were to try to replicate, for instance, a study with a strong pro-null BF result, but I won't get into that here). Using sig. main hypothesis t-test results were ideal for us to introduce/demonstrate our method in a straightforward way. 2. It is rare for people to report null results for their primary hypotheses. If I recall correctly, none of the authors did so for the 2015/2016 psych sci articles I searched through (that is, no single results were reported that were null, though once or twice I saw cases where there was a mix of sig. and non sig.). If we were to only look at these, we'd have had basically no data. 

I think reanalyzing a mixture of results (both sig. and non sig.) would have made the demonstration more complex than we would want it to be.

Certainly it can, but I wouldn't ever recommend people use NHST unless they are very clear on the Fisherian and N/P schools of thought, and know what their results can (and cannot) say. My issue is that the scenario you mention is very complicated with NHST because you don't know the reason for either the sig. result or the non sig. result.

I am not sure I agree that the goal of the full evaluation procedure is speed. I would rather make the point that, given that it does take a long time to properly assess the value of replicating a particular original study, your Bayes factor filter approach allows researchers to target their qualitative evaluations more strategically. 

However, I would be very curious to see any time estimates you may have. Do you have a ball-park for how much time the total assessment process for the example in this paper took?
On the other hand, supplementary materials (which could be posted on open repositories) or submission of meta-data to services like Curate Science, should still be a viable strategy in this case, no?

I miss a critical discussion of the ability of article 12's study design to adequately address the substantive hypothesis of interest, before this conclusion is reached. If what we are interested in is the experience of recognition of God's existence on risk taking *behavior*, then is a priming paradigm with a self-report outcome really the design we should invest resources in replicating? I do not have a definite answer, but I think such considerations should be part of the reflection on study methodology.
Given the p values reported for these effects, is it perhaps also possible to criticize the test outcomes based on p-curve logic? (i.e. probability of getting three p-s between .05 and .01 is low).
Perhaps directly cite these studies directly in the text? Would make it easier for me to look them up while reading.
doesn't the need for further (close) replication depend on the conclusiveness of the existing replication?

Could the focus on significant results sometimes lead one astray? E.g. what happens in cases where one important result is non-significant and one important result is highly significant, and both bear on the same hypothesis.
Do you mean 4a through 4c?
I think there is something grammatically strange about this sentence. I am not sure what "all" is referring to.
The discussion of replication taxonomy as a continuum by LeBel et al. may be of relevance to this paragraph. See for example: http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/pspi0000106
[Kuhberger's commentary](https://doi.org/10.31234/osf.io/wuh8t) to Zwaan, Lucas and Donnellan (2017) may be of relevance to this argument:

It is not clear to me why this should be a criterion. According to your own introductory explanations, it seems to me that it would be equally interesting, if not more, to inspect claims of non-existence of an effect based on a non-significant NHST. Am I overlooking something here?
suggestion: "from *the*"
suggestion: "... 2016 *issues of the journal* Psychological Science..."
Maybe cite with last name and an opinion piece/editorial? E.g. [his 2013 Cortex editorial](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cortex.2012.12.016)

I think it might be helpful to state what the prior and alternative hypothesis is for this example, since these parameters partly determine the Bayes factor, and they also contribute to differences between conclusions drawn about evidence from p-values vs Bayes factors.
Missing first half of sentence.

Possibly this is phrased a bit too simplistically. Especially the efforts of the more vulnerable Island States and Least Developed Countries since COP21, and the promotion of fossil fuels by for instance the USA seem to go against this statement.

My first online comments on a preprint !
I highlighted only negative points (sorry)

Please provide more details about this NA management strategy

The absence of several covariates is a major weakness. Hughes et al 2017 concluded "Associations were weak or modest for physical inactivity, overweight or obesity, and diabetes ...; moderate for smoking, heavy alcohol use, poor self-rated health, cancer, heart disease, and respiratory disease ..., strong for sexual risk taking, mental ill health, and problematic alcohol use ..., and strongest for problematic drug use and interpersonal and self-directed violence". Consequently, all MLMs should minimally include smoking and alcohol use and chronic illness (Y/N). These variables are associated with adverse childhood experiences (Anda JAMA 99) but also with depression (10.1080/15504260902870129).
maybe "self-reported" PA
maybe "retrospective assessment of child"... see Edwards et al. 2001 in Child Abuse Neg
You should use a more adapted term. Do you present findings examining the associations between functional dependence and "depressive symptoms", major depressive disorder, depressive disorders?
reminds me of the Matthes Scale

Diesem Manuskript scheint grundsätzlich ein teleologisches Verständnis zu Grunde zu liegen. Aus diesem "Ziel" von Dialog und dem Erreichen oder Nicht-Erreichen dieses Ziel scheinen sich dann die in der Intr. angesprochenen normativen Implikationen ("good" / "bad") zu ergeben. An dieser Stelle frage ich mich als Leser, was genau dieses Ziel ist. Dies wird implizit angesprochen, eine direkte Auseinandersetzung damit, welches (normativ oder wie auch immer begründete) Ziel verfolgt wird könnte man direkt zu Beginn noch stärker herausarbeiten.
In this context, are these diversity estimates just 'raw' counts (based on first/last occurrences), or have they been corrected/standardised in some way?
Font type and size differs across figures. We might want to keep it consistent if possible.
I might be missing something but some of these references have DOIs and some don't. Can't find a pattern though.
Font size in this figure needs to be larger. Almost needed a magnifying glass ;)

Are we proposing any solution to this problem, or merely stating this as a potential problem?  For example, are we saying that we will control race/ethnicity in the analysis or include labs from non-white regions?

Really interesting paper!

2. akan lebih bagus kalau data mentah diunggah ke INArxiv sebagai suplemen dari artikel.

Yth para penulis. Ini artikel menarik. Selamat sudah terbit. Namun demikian mohon dicek perjanjian pengalihan hak cipta ke penerbit IJET, karena yang ibu dan bapak unggah ini adalah yang versi penerbit (ada logo dll). Terima kasih.

It would be possible to start this sentence with "While", then after what is written here mention that Bayes factors have recently been critiqued. 

So something like: Although Bayes factors have been proposed as an alternative to....they also have several important limitations that have recently been noted in the psychological literature (cite (1), see discussion: cite (2)).


(1) Carlsson, R., Schimmack, U., Williams, D. R., & Bürkner, P. C. (2017). Bayes factors from pooled data are no substitute for Bayesian meta-Analysis: commentary on Scheibehenne, Jamil, and Wagenmakers (2016). Psychological science, 28(11), 1694-1697.

(2) Quintana, D. S., & Williams, D. R. (2018). Bayesian alternatives for common null-hypothesis significance tests in psychiatry: a non-technical guide using JASP. BMC psychiatry, 18(1), 178.

PS:
Apologies in advance for the self citation, but I think these two are good because some of the authors are Bayesians. This makes it pretty clear that even Bayesians do not agree with the Bayes factor advocacy in psychology.

For an additional citation to contrast the advocacy of Bayesian methods being less problematic for optional stopping see: [https://arxiv.org/abs/1708.08278](https://arxiv.org/abs/1708.08278). So I think, in addition to what you stated here (quite the effort to learn new methods), it could also be stated that it is not so clear Bayesian methods are, in general, immune to optional stopping (see the appendix in the linked paper). Rather, it occurs under very specific assumptions that do not often reflect how Bayesian methods is used in practice.
Would love to know what this citation is.
Thanks for this, the abstract is really nicely written, and conveys the importance of this research very well. Two thumbs up!

Very nice review. Please note the reference [94] (Pantazatos et al.) is misplaced because they did not argue that spatial biases cannot entirely explain the putative links between CGE and functional segregation. Instead, they argued there was insufficient evidence in the original Richiardi et al. study linking elevated CGE with resting state functional networks, and that spatial biases may in fact entirely account for their findings. To describe the debate/exchange more accurately, I would suggest replacing the below sentence 

“While spatial biases may contribute to these findings, as nodes belonging to the same module tend to be anatomically colocalized [7,8], they cannot explain these effects entirely [94,95].”

with the below paragraph:

“Spatial biases may contribute to these findings, as nodes belonging to the same module tend to be anatomically colocalized [7,8]. Pantazatos et al. argued that these findings are entirely explained by spatial biases [94]. They showed that elevated CGE, as defined in the original Richiardi et al. study, falls monotonically as longer distance edges are removed. Moreover, they showed that 1,000 sets of randomly spaced modules all have significantly high CGE when using the same null distribution defined in the original Richiardi et al. analyses. Therefore, elevated CGE is not specifically related to functional segregation as defined by resting state functional networks, which is in direct contradiction to the main conclusion of the original Richiardi et al. study. Since randomly placed modules do not align (spatially) with any distributed pattern of functional segregation, the finding of elevated CGE may instead be attributed entirely to anatomical colocalization of the nodes within each module. In their rebuttal to [94], Richiardi et al. argue spatial biases cannot explain their findings entirely [95]. However, the authors do not offer an explanation for significantly high CGE observed for randomly spaced sets of modules, other than to note that nodes tend to be closer on average compared to when modules are defined by resting state fMRI. Future work is required to dissociate the effects of spatially proximity on relationships between CGE and spatially distributed functional networks.”

Link to the OSF project page:

It is worth pointing out the reform movement is in no way guided by simplistic and orthodox Popperian views on science - this transition to a less strict falsificationist view on research has already occurred (see Meehl, 1990) so the author seems to be amused by a strawmen. The current reform movement is more diverse, and less single-mindedly focused on Popper, as the author argues here.

**Concluding thoughts**
I think this manuscript omits an important discussion regarding potential issues that CodeBlue may face in the future. What measures are in place to ensure that the information is stored securely? How long is the storage of the information guaranteed (e.g., what would happen to everybody's data if the company went bankrupt?). What issues are the CodeBlue team currently grappling with?

I am also curious about version control. I see in the contact hypothesis capsule that different versions of the project exist, but are these versions created every time a change is made or do authors control when changes will appear as a new version?  For example, if an author changed the dataset that accompanied the code, would there be viewable documentation of this change?

One neat feature that was not emphasized in the manuscript is the ability for a viewer to *privately* test changes in the code (e.g., change an argument in a function and receive up-to-date results) and that these changes are saved across sessions. However, CodeBlue seems to currently lack a way to see the changes that one has made (but does possess a feature to revert back to the original document).

I think it is critical that the authors describe the financial cost model of CodeBlue. CodeBlue is better described as "freemium" than "free". Academics can use the platform for free, but face private storage (20GB) and computation time (10 hrs/month) limits. For $20 per individual, researchers unlock more features. I think this cost model is perfectly ok and reasonable, but it should be more transparently discussed in the article.
Can the authors clarify which figure they are referencing? I did not find any interactive widgets when I pulled this article.
Compared to what?
The paper currently relies to heavily on direct quotes that I suspect could be more succinctly summarized by the writers.
I feel that this part of the quote makes it very difficult to read and I'm not sure if it is entirely necessary

I think the role of computational reproducibility is being oversold here. Computational irreproducibility, malfeasance, and human error are all potential reasons for such discrepencies. However, one of the nice things about computational irreproduciblity is that it makes it easier to uncover malfeasance and human error.

I think the distinction between statistical, empirical, and computational reproducible is useful. However, there seems to be some clear overlap between these types of reproducible. For example, a set of code that categorizes a set of tweets based on emotion tone and performs a variety of analyses seems to provide both computational and statistical reproducibility. While Code Ocean clearly seems designed for computational reproducibility, I am having trouble seeing how it is also not providing statistical reproducibility.

It might be good to give an example of this. Knowing where I live and where I work might be identifiable if the organization is small. Adding a third piece of knowledge (strong political views, or type of car I drive...) could re-identify many more people.

It might be worth adding some resources for how to accomplish this. These protected access repositories provide this type of service as a 3rd party protection to identifiable information: https://osf.io/tvyxz/wiki/8.%20Approved%20Protected%20Access%20Repositories/
We look forward to your comments!

I really enjoyed this preprint. I have one comment: Throughout this manuscript, you reference univariate effect sizes. It seems relevant to reference a multivariate effect (i.e., Mahalanobis D) if only to make the point that even small mean differences in univariate preferences, personality traits, and cognitive abilities can combine to create perceivably large gender/sex differences. I know this topic is debated (and the authors are critical of D and what is means), but this thesis seems incomplete without reference to how preferences/traits/abilities could combine to create differences in what majors/jobs/careers men and women are good at/pursue (on average). I think the commentaries here (https://marcodgdotnet.files.wordpress.com/2014/04/delgiudice_etal_2012_comments_reply.pdf) and the examples described here (https://marcodgdotnet.files.wordpress.com/2014/04/delgiudice_2013_is-d_valid_ep.pdf) make the debate and the conceptual utility of D clear.

This is written with the assumption that passing a threshold should be a requirement for publication, yet this argument was dismantled on page 10, lines 186-190, where it's written that a threshold should only be used for a semantic label ("significant") and not as a criterion for publication.
yes, we went from comparing it to the GDS system airlines use, to real time information channel to information pipeline. we settled on information sharing pipeline.

I'd also add that even detailed preregistrations are not sufficient. They must be followed, deviations must be justifiable, and reviewers must check those. Finally, authors should not be penalized for deviations in a system where prereg isn't common because that would further incentive unreported flexibility/p-hacking by those who didn't preregister.

This is an interesting paper. However, I am worried that it is published a few years too late: More and more researchers seem to recognize the value of RDI-plots which plot the Raw data, Descriptive statistics, and Inferential data (see e.g., here for an example https://www.r-bloggers.com/the-pirate-plot-an-r-pirates-favorite-plot/). 
Barplots and line-graphs are riddled with problems, no matter whether the y-axis is restricted or not. Weissgerber et al. (2015) discuss a few of them http://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.1002128

In sum, it would be great if the author could discuss these two points.

Hi Darias and colleagues. I have reviewed your manuscript for a podcast episode we are hoping to record and annotated my thoughts on the submission in the hope that some may be of use. You should note that I'm not a physiologist and part of the point of my reviewing the work is as an educated outsider who isn't overly familiar with the topic. As such, some of the comments may be nonsense! Anyway, I hope they are of some use!
I'd stick to information processing here personally.
This needs explaining as it's the first time it is brought up
Relating back to the hypotheses would be useful throughout the results.
Are you sure you want to frame this result in this way?
Reporting the p-value would be useful here. You're a little inconsistent in the way you report p > .05 (see five lines up).
These all feel like they should have been introduced earlier on as this is the first time I recall seeing them discussed. Be careful not to HARK though.
A citation here would be useful.
You still want to know that their responses were internally consistent though, right?
You don't say why. Also, what does Chronbach's Alpha have to do with test-retest reliability? The phrasing here could be tweaked to clarify these points.
Has this not been used for research before as there is no citation?
Should be earlier too. I'm sure you haven't, but this kind of implies you've switched the studies around in the way that they're being reported.
Same here. There should be a level of consistency in the way you report each measure.

Is this different to study 1? If it is different then I would expected similar detail for the measure used in study 1. If it is the same then you need this earlier and just a note to state that it's the same measure here.
Why a set amount in study 2?
I'm a psychologist and haven't heard of this? Also, was this discussed in the methods?
How do you handle observer-expectancy effects here?

What are the pros and cons to this?

I'd expect to see example items, the number of items, prior evidence of internal consistency, and citations reported here as minimum.
Why?
I think the estimated sample size should be reported here.

These lessons will be useful and probably invaluable to other practitioners and policy makers. There is an extraordinary amount of tactical and technical advice here, and kudos to the author. That being said, I realize this paper is on public participation in the RAP process so perhaps this is outside the scope, but one point that is not mentioned is the importance to RAP that both major political parties in Australia supported the rezoning process at the time. This unification of political support may in fact have been essential as it allowed stakeholders nowhere to turn for political power if they wanted to stop it. It should be noted that if RAP were attempted today – with the current ruling party actively rolling back Australia’s MPA regulations nationwide – the rezoning would be much harder to achieve, if not impossible. Again, perhaps this is outside the scope of public participation, which this paper does a very solid job of covering. But the realities of Australian politics at the time were key to supporting a result that today might not happen.

This is an invaluable paper. The author is an academic now but he was a manager at the time of RAP, and there are all too few manager-level analyses of which tactics actually work in an MPA planning/rezoning process.

I think this paper and these data could be extremely useful for psychologists, but I also think this paper needs at least one more analysis: estimating effect sizes by research area, controlling for publication bias.

It's very hard to interpret these estimates given good evidence and arguments that researchers and journals select for p < .05. I think it's safe to assume that all these estimates reported in this preprint are bigger than the true averages ([Simonsohn, Nelson, & Simmons, 2014](https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2377290)).

One approach to estimating "selection bias adjusted" effects would be to estimate the effect size for each research area using the code provided in the p-curve effect size paper supplements (http://www.p-curve.com/Supplement/). You could estimate confidence intervals or percentiles using bootstrapping procedures or write code to estimate the lower and upper bounds using the same methods to estimate the average effect.

This approach assumes the p-values all test the hypothesis of interest and don't suffer from unique selection biases (see Selecting p Values in [Simonsohn, Nelson, & Simmons, 2014](https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2256237), p. 540).
